answers.answer: I would like to add that her joint pain has 'spread' and is now in other joints such as her ankles, wrists, and elbows although it seems to remain the most predominant in her knees.  Her knees also hurt very badly after she fainted.  She becomes dizzy upon standing and sometimes for no apparent reason and once lost her vision for around 5 minutes during a 'dizzy' attack.  She has A LOT of trouble focusing in school and may have some memory issues as well.  We have suspect ADD in the past.  Does this sound familiar to anyone?  Any suggestions of other directions (besides neurology)?  Any ideas at all would be good.  We just want a diagnosis so that we can treat or at least know what we're dealing with.

Hi there. Please get your child investigated in detail for possible insulin dependent diabetes mellitus since she was detected with hypoglycemia and urinary ketones. the fainting could be hypoglycemic coma. Then you need to get your neurologist to rule out absence seizures which can occur.  Rule out hypocalcaemia as the cause of joint pains. Consult a neurologist for a detailed evaluation and appropriate investigations to hasten her treatment. Take care.

question: My daughter (15) has been experiencing severe joint pain in her knees since around 6  years of age which has progressively become worse.  She has reported in the last 3 years or so that she has been dizzy and nauseated.  She often becomes nauseated and gags but usually does not throw up.  We found her face-down on the computer keyboard this weekend.  She had fainted from a sitting position.  I assume she fainted.  She was unconscious.  When I pulled her from the chair, her eyes opened but she was unresponsive and her eyes did not focus on or follow anyone but they were not rolled up into her head.  We have had numerous tests for inflammation and RA which are negative.  She frequently becomes ill with everything that goes around the school.  One time in the ER her blood sugar was low but it did not continue to be low.  The last time in the ER (when she fainted), she had some ketones in her urine but her blood sugar was OK.  She has also suffered with depression and anxiety in the last couple of years.  We are going to see a neurologist next month.  I don't know if this is the right direction or not but she has missed a lot of school and we are concerned about her future if she continues to be this ill so much of the time.
title: Joint pain, nausea, dizziness, and fainting
